thread.title: Singapore economy grows 1.4% in Q3, narrowly escaping technical recession – 14 Oct 2015
thread.title_full: Singapore economy grows 1.4% in Q3, narrowly escaping technical recession – 14 Oct 2015

author: centennial
title: Singapore economy grows 1.4% in Q3, narrowly escaping technical recession – 14 Oct 2015
text: Home › The Asian Pulse › Daily News › Singapore economy grows 1.4% in Q3, narrowly escaping technical recession – 14 Oct 2015 Singapore economy grows 1.4% in Q3, narrowly escaping technical recession – 14 Oct 2015 Wednesday, October 14th, 2015 The economy grew 1.4% in 3Q15, beating economists’ estimates by a hair’s breadth and just barely escaping a technical recession, advance estimates out on 14 Oct showed. Economists had tipped a 1.2% y/y expansion for 3Q15, amid a marked growth slowdown in China, hazy conditions, and turbulent stock market activity. The economy grew 0.1% q/q, escaping a technical recession – two straight q/q declines in economic output – which had been widely predicted by analysts. The manufacturing sector was the biggest drag on growth, contracting 6% y/y in 3Q15, following a 4.9% y/y decline in the 2Q15. For a long time, investors have been right to assume that China’s policy makers would do enough to prevent the multiple imbalances in its economy from coalescing into a major slowdown or even a full-blown crisis. That assumption may not be valid anymore: Not only is China’s economy losing momentum despite a range of policy measures last year but the imbalances appear more threatening than befo What will drive global markets? Financial markets have been on a wild ride since the year began. Prices of equities, bonds, currencies and commodities have fluctuated, sometimes wildly, and have confounded the forecasts of the best pundits. How does an investor make sense of this market turbulence? Perhaps a good starting point is to try and clarify the likely directions that the major determinants of investment returns - cashfl Singapore: Where is the economy heading? The portents for the Singapore economy have been mixed of late. Despite a strong labour market buoying retail sales, other drivers of growth are flagging. The global economy has been disappointing, with weakness in the Eurozone, Japan and China offsetting a strengthening American economy.
